Package com.tc_4.carbon_counter.controllers

Class UserController

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.tc_4.carbon_counter.controllers.UserController
  • @RestController
public class UserController
extends java.lang.Object
    The user controller provides an API to send commands to the back end. The controller provides url mappings to specific logic in the service classes. The user controller deals with all mappings beginning with /user/. The server may respond with a "401 unauthorized" status code if the authentication header is not correct. It should be a string in the following format "username:password" and it should be 64 bit encoded. This header must be attached to all requests except /user/add. Some functions require elevated permissions to access, these are handled by the UnauthorizedException, the response body will contain a json object with a message parameter with further details.
    Author:
    Colton Glick, Andrew Pester
    See Also:
    UserService

      • getUserInfo

        @GetMapping("/user/{username}")
public User getUserInfo​(@PathVariable
                        java.lang.String username)
        Get user info by username.
        Parameters:
        username - pass as a path variable
        Returns:
        The user's info as a JSON object

      • addUser

        @PostMapping("/user/add")
public User addUser​(@RequestBody
                    User user)
        Add a user to the database, required fields: username, email, password, role. Does not require authentication.
        Parameters:
        user - to add, pass as a JSON object in the request body.
        Returns:
        the user that has been added, may include additional details from the server.
        See Also:
        User, User.Role

      • setUserPassword

        @RequestMapping("/user/{username}/setPassword")
public boolean setUserPassword​(@PathVariable
                               java.lang.String username,
                               @RequestParam("newPassword")
                               java.lang.String newPassword)
        Change a user's password. Must be authenticated with at least admin permissions or authenticated as the user to change
        Parameters:
        username - provide as a path variable
        newPassword - new password, provide as a request parameter
        Returns:
        boolean, if the password was set

      • editUser

        @PostMapping("/user/edit/{username}")
public User editUser​(@PathVariable
                     java.lang.String username,
                     @RequestBody
                     User changes)
        Edit a user's information. Overwrites the user that has the username given in the path, with the information passed in the JSON object. All user variables are optional only specified values will be updated. ID cannot be edited. Must be authenticated with at least admin permissions or authenticated as the user to change. example: authenticated as admin user or userToEdit. path= /user/edit/userToEdit body = {"email":"EditedEmail","username":"EditedUsername"}
        Parameters:
        username - provide as a path variable. The current username of the user to change
        changes - provide in the request body as a json object. This contains the new values to change to.
        Returns:
        The updated user.

      • friendRequest

        @RequestMapping("/user/friend_request/{user}")
public boolean friendRequest​(@PathVariable
                             java.lang.String user,
                             @RequestParam
                             java.lang.String username)
        Parameters:
        user - the user sending the friend request
        username - the user being sent the friend request
        Returns:
        true if it sends the request otherwise throws userNotFoundException or RequestExistsException

      • removeUser

        @DeleteMapping("/user/{username}")
public java.lang.Boolean removeUser​(@PathVariable
                                    java.lang.String username)
        Remove this user from the database. Must be authenticated with at least admin permissions or authenticated as the user to remove.
        Parameters:
        username - provide as a path variable. The current username of the user to remove
        Returns:
        boolean, true if the user was successfully removed
